author: By Alanis Thames
title: Iowa Beats Penn State, Staking Claim Atop Big Ten Playoff Contenders
description: The No. 3 Hawkeyes got past the No. 4 Nittany Lions in a year where several teams in the conference are making they case that they should be among the semifinalists for a national title.
content: On a day that saw 103 combined points in two early afternoon college football games, Iowa and Penn State deviated from the day’s script.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: ‘Go out there and enjoy Halloween,’ Dr. Fauci says.
description: Some towns have canceled celebrations, but Dr. Fauci says outdoor trick-or-treating is perfectly safe.
content: Despite the wide availability of Covid-19 vaccines, not all Halloween parades have been safe from virus-related cancellations this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: ‘What Have We Done With Democracy?’ A Decade On, Arab Spring Gains Wither
description: Tunisia, birthplace of the pro-democracy uprisings that swept the Arab world, now looks to many like a final confirmation of failed promise.
content: TUNIS, Tunisia — For roughly three months after Tunisians toppled their dictator in January 2011 in an eruption of protest that electrified the Arab world, Ali Bousselmi felt nothing but “pure happiness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Frank Sanchez wins in a battle among undefeated fighters.
description: Frank Sanchez defeated Efe Ajagba via unanimous decision in Saturday’s co-main event to retain his heavyweight belt and undefeated record.
content: Frank Sanchez defeated Efe Ajagba via unanimous decision in Saturday’s co-main event to retain his heavyweight belt and undefeated record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Hot New Back-to-School Accessory? An Air Quality Monitor.
description: Parents are sneaking carbon dioxide monitors into their children’s schools to determine whether the buildings are safe.
content: When Lizzie Rothwell, an architect in Philadelphia, sent her son to third grade this fall, she stocked his blue L.L. Bean backpack with pencils, wide-ruled paper — and a portable carbon dioxide monitor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Black Lives Matter, She Wrote. Then ‘Everything Just Imploded.’
description: A Black superintendent’s email to parents after the killing of George Floyd engulfed a small, predominantly white Maryland community in a yearlong firestorm.
content: CENTREVILLE, Md. — When Andrea Kane sat down to write a letter to parents in her school district days after George Floyd’s death in 2020, images of the Black man pleading for his life under the knee of a white Minnesota police officer were haunting her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Southwest Airlines’ Widespread Cancellations Disrupt Weekend Travel
description: More than a thousand flights were canceled on Sunday and 800 on Saturday. The airline blamed air traffic control and “disruptive weather,” but no other carrier reported problems.
content: Southwest Airlines canceled more than 1,000 flights on Sunday and just over 800 on Saturday, wreaking havoc on weekend travel plans for thousands of passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: For One Bill Cosby Juror, the Work Did Not End With the Trial
description: Stunned by what she learned about the law during deliberations in the sex assault case, Cheryl Carmel is lobbying for consent to have a clear definition: a positive, unequivocal “yes.”
content: Some jurors were stunned during deliberations in Bill Cosby’s 2018 trial on sexual assault charges when they asked the judge for the legal definition of consent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: He Finds Women on Dating Apps. Then They Disappear.
description: After you finish Lisa Unger’s new novel, “Last Girl Ghosted,” you might think twice before swiping right.
content: “If you remember me at all, you remember the shy, slight, discomfited and fatherless soul known to inhabit every little nothing town like ours,” Wayland Maynard, ex-resident of Shireburne, Vt., writes to his former neighbors in 2020, in a confessional manuscript describing events that took place more than 40 years earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Happy to Pitch for the Rays, Team U.S.A. or Westcott Properties
description: When David Robertson joined Tampa Bay’s motley crew of low-cost high-reward options, the former Yankees closer said he was up for “whatever.” He meant it.
content: BOSTON — The pitching arm is extremely demanding. You can’t just ignore it and expect it to work when you need it. Thankfully, though, it isn’t picky. Just ask David Robertson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Weiner
title: Abdul Qadeer Khan, Father of Pakistan’s Nuclear Program, Dies at 85
description: Starting from scratch in 1976, he acquired the technology and knowledge that allowed Pakistan to detonate its first nuclear device in 1998.
content: Abdul Qadeer Khan, a metallurgist who became known to Western intelligence services as the father of Pakistan’s nuclear bomb and a worldwide dealer in weapons technology, died Sunday at a hospital in Islamabad, Pakistan. He was believed to be 85 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Austrian Political Scandal Leaves Europe’s Conservatives in Need of New Path
description: Chancellor Sebastian Kurz was young, adept at social media and unafraid to borrow from populists, but in his downfall, some see “the collapse of a new narrative” for European conservatives.
content: BERLIN — When Sebastian Kurz first became chancellor of Austria the whole of Europe sat up. Only 31, he had turned around the fortunes of his ailing conservative party and almost overnight become a role model for struggling center-right leaders elsewhere on the Continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Coach’s Vaccine Refusal Generates Discord at Washington State
description: Nick Rolovich’s job could be in jeopardy if he does not get vaccinated or receive an exemption, as required of state employees and students. “It’s the No. 1 question,” said Kirk Schulz, the university’s president.
content: PULLMAN, Wash. — With the leaves beginning to turn and the chilly air snapping skin to attention, Washington State’s football players awoke Saturday to a crisp fall morning. Walking into Martin Stadium through a gantlet of fans, parents, cheerleaders and a marching band only amplified their anticipation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Powerful Story of Coming to America, Finding Promise and Paradox
description: In “Concepcion,” Albert Samaha writes about several generations of his family, from their long history in the Philippines to their move to the United States.
content: “Why was America so kind and yet so cruel?” Carlos Bulosan wrote in “America Is in the Heart,” his 1943 semi-autobiographical novel about a young Filipino immigrant bewildered by the paradox of his new home. Here, he found racism, callousness and brutality; but he also found good will, tolerance and generosity. “Was there no way to simplify things in this continent so that suffering would be minimized?” Bulosan wrote. “Was there no common denominator on which we could all meet?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Wilder-Fury Yields Not Another Rematch, but a Path to a Unified Title
description: After beating Deontay Wilder and retaining his heavyweight belt, Tyson Fury can target the winner of the rematch between Anthony Joshua and Oleksandr Usyk.
content: Late in the 10th round of their heavyweight title fight on Saturday, Tyson Fury floored Deontay Wilder with a clubbing right hand to the jaw, and the end of their brawl seemed imminent. But Wilder climbed off the canvas and spent the late stages of the round landing heavy punches as Fury covered up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Iraqis’ Frustration Over Broken Promises Keeps Voter Turnout Low
description: Iraqis voted in parliamentary elections that were called a year early in response to anti-government protests.
content: BAGHDAD — Iraqis voted Sunday in parliamentary elections meant to herald sweeping change to a dysfunctional political system that has dragged the country through almost two decades of deprivation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Singapore’s pandemic caution.
content: Vaccines were supposed to be the city-state’s ticket back to normalcy. But even with an 83 percent vaccination rate, Singapore is not opening up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Brenda Wintrode
title: U.S. Navy Engineer Charged in Attempt to Sell Nuclear Submarine Secrets
description: Jonathan Toebbe and his wife tried several times to pass information on nuclear propulsion systems to a foreign government, according to a criminal complaint.
content: WASHINGTON — A nuclear engineer for the U.S. Navy and his wife have been charged with trying to share some of the United States’ most closely held secrets on submarine technology with another country, according to court documents unsealed on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Pfizer to vaccinate entire city in Brazil as part of study.
description: The study will follow participants for up to one year to find out how long vaccine protection lasts against Covid-19 and new variants.
content: In the southwestern Brazilian city of Toledo, you won’t find much vaccine skepticism. About 98 percent eligible residents there have received at least one dose of a Covid vaccine, according to municipal officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Anthony Geathers
title: A Street Basketball Mecca Gets a Face-Lift
description: Rucker Park in Harlem has been a proving ground for amateurs and professionals for generations. “We don’t come there giving you roses,” one player said. “You got to earn it.”
content: As a child, Michele Roberts occasionally found herself at Holcombe Rucker Park when her older brothers, who were supposed to be babysitting her at home in the South Bronx, would take her to Harlem instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: In ‘Herstory of the Universe,’ Ancient Myths Are Brought to Life
description: The choreographer Richard Move’s new work, partly inspired by Japanese, Indian and Greek mythology, wends its way across Governors Island.
content: If not for the crowd gathered around, you could have missed her: reclining in the branches of a tree, as if dozing in her natural habitat, a woman adorned in feathers and tulle. At the brisk ring of a bell, she started to stir, arching her sinewy back, the beginning of a delicate descent down to Earth from her comfortable perch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yacine Djibo
title: What the Malaria Vaccine Means for Africa
description: A new malaria vaccine should inspire even further Africa-based science.
content: Like many who work in public health, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, I’ve been waiting my whole career for a malaria vaccine. And even longer than that: I suffered from severe malaria when I was 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Giants Lose Daniel Jones and Saquon Barkley Against Cowboys
description: Quarterback Daniel Jones, after a hit to the head, and running back Saquon Barkley, with an ankle injury, were carted off the field.
content: The short-handed Giants on Sunday lost quarterback Daniel Jones, who was carted off the field after a helmet-to-helmet hit against the Dallas Cowboys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: Abortion Rights and Trans Rights Are Two Sides of the Same Coin
description: Bodily integrity matters — for all people.
content: Caitlyn Jenner’s run for California governor concluded last month, having earned her a whopping 1 percent of the final votes cast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Erin Schaff
title: ‘It’s Not Sustainable’: What America’s Port Crisis Looks Like Up Close
description: An enduring traffic jam at the Port of Savannah reveals why the chaos in global shipping is likely to persist.
content: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Like toy blocks hurled from the heavens, nearly 80,000 shipping containers are stacked in various configurations at the Port of Savannah — 50 percent more than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Not Even Alabama Is Immune From College Football’s Upset Machine
description: Texas A&M downed the top-ranked Crimson Tide with a final field goal.
content: Earlier this year, Texas A&M Coach Jimbo Fisher made a playful declaration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon and Charles McDonald
title: Are the Jets and Giants Watchable Yet?
description: With the Jets losing to the Atlanta Falcons in London after their first win of the season and the Cowboys easily cruising to a win over the Giants, our experts evaluated the teams’ prospects.
content: Time is a flat circle, but we want to help you break it. To that end, we’ve enlisted two experts — one familiar with the ins and outs of New York’s football teams, the other a nationally focused football analyst — to answer an essential question as a service to readers: Is this team good yet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How to Help Prepare Kids for Suffering
description: We should resist the temptation to shield children from the realities of the pandemic.
content: Last year, my sister was asked to write an article on how to make holidays fun for children in the middle of the pandemic. On a walk, we brainstormed about ways to celebrate without group gatherings. We wanted a respite for kids after a dark, hard year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: A Year After ‘Defund,’ Police Departments Get Their Money Back
description: The abrupt reversals have come in response to rising levels of crime, the exodus of officers and political pressures.
content: DALLAS — The demonstrators came at night, chanting and blowing whistles outside the home of Mayor Eric Johnson, protesting in occasionally personal terms his staunch refusal to cut funding to the Dallas Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: No Charges for Passenger Who Prompted La Guardia Emergency Landing
description: A spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said the authorities determined that there was “no criminality” involved in the landing.
content: A passenger whose erratic behavior prompted pilots to make an emergency landing at La Guardia Airport on Saturday afternoon was not charged after the authorities determined that he “did not make a verbal threat” and was not carrying a suspicious item, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Two Journalists Started an Argument in Boston in 1979. It’s Not Over Yet.
description: A writer for an alt-weekly called out a Boston Globe editor for his “fealty” to the idea of objectivity in a column that reads as if it were written yesterday.
content: In 1979, two journalists got into an argument. More than four decades later, they haven’t settled it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: One Killed and at Least 14 Wounded in Shooting in Minnesota Bar, Police Say
description: Investigators said that they had arrested three men who were among those wounded but had not yet determined a motive for the shooting.
content: One person was killed and at least 14 others were wounded during a shooting early on Sunday morning inside a crowded bar in St. Paul, Minn., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Finally Time for ‘No Time to Die’? The Champagne’s Been on Ice.
description: For brands associated with the Bond franchise, the connection is valuable enough to throw do-over parties for the latest film.
content: One day before “No Time to Die” started playing in American theaters on Friday, Bollinger, James Bond’s Champagne of choice, held a pre-screening bash at a swanky theater in New York’s South Street Seaport. V.I.P.s in sequined dresses and tuxedos posed for photos on the red carpet, ate caviar and drank a limited edition wine dedicated to 007 — both during the movie and for hours afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: James Bond Returns and Theaters See Reason for Hope
description: “No Time to Die” has taken in more than $300 million worldwide. The overall box office remains fragile, however, and the future for films that aren’t part of big-budget franchises is unsure.
content: LOS ANGELES — Movie theaters are finally bouncing back from the pandemic, with solid turnout over the weekend for the latest James Bond spectacle, “No Time to Die,” giving Hollywood its third box office success in the span of a month. For coronavirus-battered multiplex chains, it’s reason for a celebratory martini.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Facebook’s Rough Stretch
description: Facebook faced both an outage and a whistle-blower. Lawmakers reached a compromise on raising the debt ceiling. And the latest number on inflation is coming this week.
content: Facebook had a tough week. On Monday, the company’s family of apps, including Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger, went down for more than five hours, disrupting communication for the billions of people and many advertisers who rely on them. (The company said several errors made during maintenance caused the outage). In an interview on “60 Minutes” on Sunday and in testimony at a Senate hearing on Tuesday, Frances Haugen, a former product manager at the company, talked about what she believes is a need for more oversight of the social media giant. Ms. Haugen said that Facebook had purposefully hidden research showing its products’ negative impact on teenagers and was willing to promote harmful content because it caused users to spend more time on the site. She has also spoken with top policymakers in Brussels, Britain and France. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, rebutted the claims in a note to employees, saying the company’s research had been taken out of context.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Nurse Dies After She Is Knocked to Ground in Times Square
description: Maria Ambrocio, 58, who worked through the pandemic in a New Jersey hospital, was knocked down by a man who was fleeing after snatching a cellphone, the police said.
content: When a small community hospital in New Jersey was overrun with Covid patients, a cancer nurse dutifully showed up for work every night.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New York’s Black Pastors Urge Flock to Embrace Vaccine
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 10, 2021.
content: “The kind of conspiracies we saw in the past were real but they do not exist about these vaccines.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Stapinski
title: The 40-Year Mystery of Smutty Smiff and the Missing Rockabilly Bass
description: The improbable tale of how a unique instrument went missing in 1982 and ended up in a pawnshop a few miles from where it was lost.
content: The moment he saw the standup bass in the Jersey City pawnshop, Stephen Ulrich knew whose it was. It wasn’t just the jet-black paint job with the pink and blue trim that caught his eye. It was the word “SMUTTY” written across the bottom in big pink letters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Edgar Berlanga got a unanimous decision over Marcelo Esteban Coceres.
description: Edgar Berlanga, a 24-year-old power puncher from Brooklyn, settled in, survived a knockdown, and won a 10-round unanimous decision over Marcelo Esteban Coceres, using forward movement and heavy punches to raise a welt on Coceres’ left eye. All three judges scored the fight 96-93 for Berlanga.
content: Edgar Berlanga, a 24-year-old power puncher from Brooklyn, settled in, survived a knockdown, and won a 10-round unanimous decision over Marcelo Esteban Coceres, using forward movement and heavy punches to raise a welt on Coceres’ left eye. All three judges scored the fight 96-93 for Berlanga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: There Is Shadow Inflation Taking Place All Around Us
description: Some companies haven’t been raising prices. Instead, they’ve been cutting back customer services and conveniences, but how should that be measured?
content: Inflation has surged in 2021, with various official measurements of consumer prices rising faster than they have in years. But in a crucial respect, the data may be understating things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At the George Washington Bridge Casino, Your Bets Are a Bike Ride Away
description: You can’t gamble online in New York, but you can in New Jersey. For a group of frustrated N.F.L. bettors, that means a 15-minute trek via bicycle that saves them a $16 toll.
content: Towering majestically above the Hudson River, the George Washington Bridge is a remarkable feat of engineering to some. For others, it is a snarled, trafficky headache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Novic
title: Don’t Fear a Deafer Planet
description: We should take a cultural approach that incorporates universal design, dismantles structural barriers, and includes deaf people from the ground up.
content: In Deaf culture, we have a rich storytelling tradition, including a stable of myths passed down through generations of deaf people. One of these stories is about a planet called “Eyeth,” a utopic world where deaf people communicate freely and live without stigma. Rather than the audio-centric societies that dominate Earth, Eyeth centers the eye. In some tellings everyone on the planet is deaf; in others, the society is designed around visual communication and signed language, and everyone signs regardless of hearing status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Alyssa Lukpat
title: 87 Rescued From ‘Near-Whiteout’ Conditions During Utah Ultramarathon
description: The runners were participating in a 50-mile race when they were caught in 12 to 18 inches of snow in the Wasatch Mountain range north of Salt Lake City.
content: Kelcey McClung Stowell said she had been told to prepare for some rain and perhaps a “tiny dusting of snow” in the higher elevations before the start on Saturday of the DC Peaks 50, a 50-mile ultramarathon through the rugged mountains of Utah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Ryan Mac and Sheera Frenkel
title: After Whistle-Blower Goes Public, Facebook Tries Calming Employees
description: Employees are divided over Frances Haugen, a former product manager who testified that the company was putting profit before safety.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — At a question-and-answer session with employees last week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, was asked about Frances Haugen, a former product manager turned whistle-blower who had testified to Congress about the company’s harms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Deontay Wilder’s costume is lighter. Fury’s entrance is zanier.
description: Deontay Wilder continued the trend of entering the ring with an exotic costume. This time, though, instead of wearing a heavy armor set, he wore a red robe and red mask. The robe was accented with black feathers around the hood and a pair of silver wings on the back. Wilder claimed the attire he wore before facing Fury in February 2020 weakened his legs, contributing to the first loss of his career. This fashion choice is definitely lighter, so if he loses, that cannot be an excuse.
content: Deontay Wilder continued the trend of entering the ring with an exotic costume. This time, though, instead of wearing a heavy armor set, he wore a red robe and red mask. The robe was accented with black feathers around the hood and a pair of silver wings on the back. Wilder claimed the attire he wore before facing Fury in February 2020 weakened his legs, contributing to the first loss of his career. This fashion choice is definitely lighter, so if he loses, that cannot be an excuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Can Crypto Go Green?
description: DealBook gathered experts to debate the solutions to cryptocurrency’s climate problem.
content: The cryptocurrency industry is growing quickly, as are concerns about its environmental impact. The original and most popular crypto, Bitcoin, is energy-intensive by design, “mined” by millions of high-powered computers around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As the Train Rattled Across the Manhattan Bridge, I Shut My Eyes’
description: An invisible voice on the Q, a special delivery in the rain and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Kim Kardashian West Takes Aim at Herself in ‘S.N.L.’ Monologue
description: Kardashian West hosted an episode featuring the musical guest Halsey and a parade of celebrity cameos that included John Cena, Chris Rock and Amy Schumer.
content: When it was first announced that Kim Kardashian West would be hosting “Saturday Night Live” this weekend, the feedback was mixed — based on the reaction from some corners, you’d think they had invited Elon Musk or something.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 5 in the N.F.L.
description: Aaron Rodgers found the personnel he’d hoped for in a wild win over the Bengals, the Cardinals’ defense helped them get to 5-0 and the Buccaneers showed the Dolphins what a Florida rebuild should look like.
content: Imagine being Mason Crosby, trotting onto the field for a fourth — fourth! — attempt at a game-winning field goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Richard Schultz, Designer Who Made the Outdoors Modern, Dies at 95
description: Working for Knoll, Mr. Schultz created furniture that became classics. One standout: a sleek mesh and aluminum chaise with wheels.
content: Richard Schultz, the ingenious industrial designer whose furniture collections for Knoll, the  design laboratory that streamlined American interiors, are among the classics of modern design, died on Sept. 28 in Princeton, N.J. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Dodgers Turn Around Their Mood With Blowout Win Over Giants
description: “We just needed to see one cross the plate,” Mookie Betts said after his team followed Friday’s shutout with a 9-2 win.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Almost always positive and upbeat, Los Angeles Dodgers Manager Dave Roberts was not after Game 1 of this National League division series. While everyone else raved about San Francisco starter Logan Webb’s dominance, Roberts chafed. He wasn’t bothered so much by the results as he was by what he viewed as his hitters’ undisciplined approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: Where Parents Have Abducted Their Own Children in a Bid for Custody
description: For years, thousands of children in China have been taken and hidden. The practice rose along with the nation’s divorce rate. A new law aims to curb the practice.
content: The men and women wrestled Wang Jianna to the ground. Holding down her legs and shoulders, they pried her 6-month-old baby from her arms and took off running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Shashank Bengali
title: Electricity Is Restored in Lebanon, as Army Supplies Emergency Fuel
description: It was a temporary reprieve for a grid that has been supplying only a few hours of electricity per day, as Lebanon’s collapsing economy struggles to import fuel.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s sputtering national electricity grid went back online on Sunday after the army provided emergency fuel supplies to the government, temporarily easing a daylong outage that served as the latest ramification of the country’s economic collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: After Killings, U.K. Asks: Should Misogyny Be a Hate Crime?
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson says an emphatic no, but rights groups argue that it would add an extra layer of protection for women who face violence at the hands of men.
content: LONDON — As anger grew in Britain last week over the justice system’s approach to violence against women, the public discourse has turned to a new question: Should misogyny be considered a hate crime?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: After 18 months, the Port of San Francisco will once again welcome cruise ships.
description: Cruise ships were a symbol of the dangers of the coronavirus in 2020. But now, they’re getting ready for what could be a busy 2022 season.
content: In the early days of the pandemic, a cruise ship that would become one of the bellwethers of the outbreak, the Grand Princess, docked in the Bay Area carrying dozens of infected passengers. It was one of the last cruise ships in the world to operate before the coronavirus caused a global shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Vaccines, Child Care, Canadian Thanksgiving: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Put Off Until Later
description: Ben Pall’s puzzle offers solvers a choice.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, solvers! Today we have an impressively constructed grid from Ben Pall. Mr. Pall is a software developer who made his debut in the New York Times Crossword nearly 12 years ago at the age of 14, making him (at the time) the youngest constructor of the Will Shortz era, although he has since been dethroned by the debut of the then-13-year-old Daniel Larsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Something Shook New Hampshire. What Caused the Boom Is a Mystery.
description: The U.S. Geological Survey said it had so far found no evidence of an earthquake in all of New England during the past seven days.
content: A mysterious boom jolted New Hampshire and at least one adjoining state on Sunday morning, rattling homes, spooking pets and prompting several hundred amateur sleuths to go online to try to find out what possibly could have caused all the commotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: Major Climate Action at Stake in Fight Over Twin Bills Pending in Congress
description: Legislation aimed at infrastructure and social programs also includes big changes in energy, transportation and disaster preparation. They would amount to the most significant climate action ever taken by the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has framed this moment as the country’s best chance to save the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 10, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 10, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about the safety of New York City’s new supertall towers misstated the occupancy status of Trump World Tower. It received a final certificate of occupancy from the New York Department of Buildings in 2005; it is not among a number of properties operating under a temporary certificate of occupancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hans Buetow, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Susan Dominus
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The “Perfect Villain” for Voting Conspiracists’
description: Eric Coomer had an election-security job at Dominion Voting Systems. He also had posted anti-Trump messages on Facebook. What happened next ruined his life.
content: Over the past decade, Eric Coomer has helped make Dominion Voting Systems one of the largest providers of voting machines and software in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra Returns, With Gusto
description: The dynamic conductor Xian Zhang opened the symphony’s new season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on a balmy night in Newark.
content: NEWARK, New Jersey — Since becoming the music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in 2016, the dynamic conductor Xian Zhang has worked steadily to reflect diversity and inclusion through the institution’s programming, outreach initiatives and guest artists. This was crucial in a city where a majority of residents were Black and Latino; it also spoke to Zhang’s own experience as one of a small number of Asian female conductors leading major ensembles. These priorities were in evidence on Friday when, 557 days after its last full orchestra concert (because of the pandemic), the New Jersey Symphony opened its new season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on a balmy night in Newark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Democrats, You’re in Danger
description: With the president's agenda  stalled in Congress, many Democratic voters are growing impatient and disillusioned.
content: The Democrats are staring down real danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Atlanta Beats the Brewers at Their Own Game
description: Milwaukee has three aces, but Max Fried, who thrived in the second half, showed he is at their level.
content: MILWAUKEE — The Milwaukee Brewers won 95 games during the regular season largely because of the strength of their starting rotation and its three All-Stars: Corbin Burnes, Brandon Woodruff and Freddy Peralta. Only the Los Angeles Dodgers had a lower earned run average than the Brewers’s starting staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Helenius led big, then won because of Kownacki’s desperate low blows.
description: Late in Round 3, Robert Helenius landed a right hand and left jab that buckled Adam Kownacki’s knees. The salvo was just the latest in a string of combinations Helenius had used to open a lead on the scorecards and raise lumps on his opponent’s face.
content: Late in Round 3, Robert Helenius landed a right hand and left jab that buckled Adam Kownacki’s knees. The salvo was just the latest in a string of combinations Helenius had used to open a lead on the scorecards and raise lumps on his opponent’s face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wessel
title: The Rich Have Found Another Way to Pay Less Tax
description: During his campaign, President Biden vowed to “reform opportunity zones to fulfill their promise,” but so far the administration hasn’t proposed anything.
content: Congress tucked a provision into the 2017 tax bill that led to the creation of 8,764 tax havens across the United States called “opportunity zones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurence Steinberg
title: Does Instagram Harm Girls? No One Actually Knows.
description: The findings of psychological research are inconclusive.
content: Amid the pillorying of Facebook that has dominated the latest news cycle there is an inconvenient fact that critics have overlooked: No research — by Facebook or anyone else — has demonstrated that exposure to Instagram, a Facebook app, harms teenage girls’ psychological well-being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Sameer Yasir
title: They Were Promised a New Home. Then They Tried to Escape It.
description: Bangladesh is relocating Rohingya refugees who fled Myanmar to a vulnerable, environmentally unstable island that is giving some cause to run again.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Its name translates into “floating island,” and for up to 100,000 desperate war refugees, the low-slung landmass is supposed to be home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: It’s almost Thanksgiving in Canada, so bring out the butter tarts.
content: Good morning. They’re prepping for Thanksgiving in Canada today, brining birds and peeling spuds for the feast on Monday, getting the butter tarts ready, dripping maple syrup into the cranberry sauce, setting tables, engaging in holiday cheer. It’s amazing to think we’ll be following them in just a little more than a month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sex Positivity, Pornography and Feminism
description: Readers discuss a column by Michelle Goldberg. Also: A reader objects to calling Americans "terrible tourists."
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
